Recommended clinical management after di: Recommended clinical management after diagnosing preeclampsia
Immediate clinical evaluation to determi: Immediate clinical evaluation to determine whether hospitalization is needed.
Assess fetal growth and well-being using: Assess fetal growth and well-being using ultrasound and Doppler studies.
Determine appropriate timing of delivery: Determine appropriate timing of delivery based on case severity and gestational age.

Re-evaluation is recommended if new symp: Re-evaluation is recommended if new symptoms arise or if vital signs or lab results change.
Preeclampsia is a serious medical condit: Preeclampsia is a serious medical condition that can occur after the 20th week of pregnancy. It is characterized by elevated blood pressure and the presence of protein in the urine or signs of organ dysfunction, particularly in the liver or kidneys. If left untreated, it may lead to life-threatening complications for both mother and baby.
Symptoms can range from mild to severe,: Symptoms can range from mild to severe, and may include:
Unusual swelling of the face, hands, or: Unusual swelling of the face, hands, or feet
Pain in the upper right abdomen: Pain in the upper right abdomen
Shortness of breath or chest tightness: Shortness of breath or chest tightness
Decreased urine output or dark-colored u: Decreased urine output or dark-colored urine
Immediate medical intervention is recomm: Immediate medical intervention is recommended if any of the following criteria are present:
Blood pressure â‰¥ 140/90 mmHg on two re: Blood pressure â‰¥ 140/90 mmHg on two readings at least 4 hours apart
Proteinuria â‰¥ 300 mg/24h or Protein/Cr: Proteinuria â‰¥ 300 mg/24h or Protein/Creatinine ratio â‰¥ 0.3
Elevated creatinine â‰¥ 1.1 mg/dL or dou: Elevated creatinine â‰¥ 1.1 mg/dL or doubling of baseline
Signs of fetal compromise (growth restri: Signs of fetal compromise (growth restriction, oligohydramnios)
Elevated blood pressure without severe s: Elevated blood pressure without severe symptoms
Organ dysfunction (liver, kidney, or pla: Organ dysfunction (liver, kidney, or platelet issues)
Clinical deterioration requiring hospita: Clinical deterioration requiring hospitalization or early delivery
Associated with higher risk; requires cl: Associated with higher risk; requires close monitoring and delivery planning.
Often less severe but still warrants clo: Often less severe but still warrants close surveillance.
Additional markers: eGFR, BUN/Creatinine: Additional markers: eGFR, BUN/Creatinine ratio, PLT/MAP ratio
If not managed, preeclampsia can lead to: If not managed, preeclampsia can lead to:
Maternal and/or fetal death in severe ca: Maternal and/or fetal death in severe cases
While preeclampsia cannot always be prev: While preeclampsia cannot always be prevented, risk can be reduced through:
Low-dose aspirin (81 mg daily starting a: Low-dose aspirin (81 mg daily starting at 12 weeks) in high-risk patients
Managing chronic conditions like hyperte: Managing chronic conditions like hypertension or diabetes
Monitoring weight gain and fluid retenti: Monitoring weight gain and fluid retention
